question: (2100-1600 BCE) First Chinese dynasty, thought to be a myth,  Huang-ti (Yellow Emperor) emerged from tribal system in prehistoric China, musical instruments, silk, law and customers, medicine, agriculture, Emperor Yao, Yellow River flood, Gun, Yu the Great
(1600-1050 BCE) Marked beginning of Chinese civilization, writing system invented, practice of divination, walled cities, bronze technology, horse-drawn chariots

(1046-256 BCE) Hierarchical social/political system, royal house at apex, similar to feudalism with power in aristocratic families as lords, ancestral cults, stability and cohesion, competition between states - Spring and Autumn period (770-475 BCE) and Warring States period (475-221 BCE), Confucius (561-479 BCE)
(221-206 BCE) Unitary state, centralized administration, standarized writing script, created weights and measures, harsh methods of rule, suppressed dissenting thought

(206 BCE - 220 CE) Consolidated foundation of imperial order, Confucianism established as orthodoxy, civil service exams, extended to Kora and Vietnam, 'Records of the Historian' - model for subsequent official histories
(220-589) Also Six Dynasties Period, fragmented empire, North dominated by invaders from the borderland and the steppe, South was ruled by successive 'Chinese' dynaties, Buddhism spread
(589-618) China reuinfied, Emperor Wen, equal-field system, standarized coinage, Buddhism spread again, golden age of agricultural surplus and population growth

(618-906) Cosmopolitanism and cultural flowering, height of Buddhist influence in China, Buddhism began being repressed around 845, active territorial expansion, defeated by Arabs at Talas (751) and expansion halted

(960-1279) Economic/social changes, monetization of the economy, growth in commerce and maritine trade, urban/technological expansion, examination system for bureaucratic recruitment, neo-Confucianism
(1279-1368) Founded by Mongols as they conquered much of the known world, Beijing made capital, dramas like 'Story of the Western Wing' flourished

(1568-1644) Emperor Hongwu laid basis of authoritarian political culture, early expansion but inward-looking overall, emphasis on agrarian base, commercial sector grew, vibrant literacy scene represent by publication of 'Journey to the West' novel

(1644-1912) Manchu dynasty, continued economic development of late Ming - prosperity but complacency, dramatic increase in population, famous novel 'Dream of the Red Chamber' written, substantial new territorial gains, authoritarian structure couldn't meet military/cultural challenge of expansive West

(1912-1949) Weak central government following dynastic system collapse, Western influence in science and democracy during New Culture Movement, Nationalist effort (1928) thwarted by domestic revolts and Japanese occupation (1937-1945), Nationalists fled to Taiwan after defeat by Communists

(1949-Present) Communist government, goal of remaking society ended in disasters like the Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution, economic reform and political enrichment have occurred since 1978
